newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: APEC not plugging into U.S. info-tech plan.
newsitem.headline: APEC not plugging into U.S. info-tech plan.

text.p: A U.S. plan to free global trade in computers and telecommunications at the turn of the century appeared to be floundering on Friday at an annual conference of Asia-Pacific nations.

Washington had hoped the 18-member Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum would give a ringing endorsement to its plan to cut tariffs to zero by the year 2000 on a broad range of information technology products.
Instead, trade and foreign ministers, meeting ahead of APEC's summit on Monday, would probably issue a vague statement welcoming ongoing negotiations in Geneva on such a pact, delegates said.

"We've worked out language that's acceptable," said a senior representative from a Latin American delegation. "It will say that efforts in Geneva to conclude an ITA (information Technology Agreement) are endorsed by APEC.
"But we don't want to prejudge the outcome in Geneva by having negotiations about it here (at APEC)," the delegate said.
The stakes are high. Washington says the information technology business is worth $1.8 trillion and the United States accounts for 60 percent of it.
The United States wanted APEC to endorse the ITA to give the pact a head start when it is submitted at next month's inaugural World Trade Organisation meeting in Singapore.
U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky told a conference of APEC business leaders that information technology products were the infrastructure of the 21st Century.
"They are and will be to that century what roads and bridges were in the 19th century, " Barshefsky said.

Japan's Trade Minister Shinji Sato told Reuters on Friday that while Tokyo and Washington were enthusiastic, "we should not push it too strongly here, because we might invite the suspicion of other members".
Washington put a brave face on the pact's fate at APEC.
"I won't be able to give you box score right now because (negotiations) are going on even as we sit here," said Ambassador John Wolf, the American coordinator for APEC.
U.S. State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said: "I can tell you progress has been made today, but we're not at the end of this process."
Malaysia and some other developing countries object to the tariff targets and timeframes in the pact, saying it undermines the essential volunteerism of the diverse group.

"There must be assurances that flexibilities are given to such countries that need flexibility in the area of the timeframe and in product coverage," Malaysia's Minister of International Trade and Industry told Reuters Financial Television.
Asked if she thought the WTO meeting in Singapore could endorse the ITA agreement in its current form, Rafidah Aziz said: "As it stands I doubt it very much."
The European Union accused the United States this week of undermining the ITA by trying to exclude important categories of goods, which U.S. trade officials denied.
APEC decisions are based on consensus, which means crafting language that is acceptable to all members.
Rodolfo Severino, the undersecretary in the Philippine Foreign Ministry, said ministers would reach a consensus on the accord.
"I think that some formula will be arrived at with the approval of all ministers, which will take into account members' concerns," Severino said.
